metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: Python Dictionaries

content.code_html:
thisdict = {
  "brand": "Ford",
  "model": "Mustang",
  "year": 1964
}

content.text: Dictionary
Dictionaries are used to store data values in key:value pairs.
content.html: Dictionaries are used to store data values in key:value pairs.

content.text: A dictionary is a collection which is ordered*, changeable and do not allow duplicates.
content.html: A dictionary is a collection which is ordered*, changeable and do not allow duplicates.

content.text: As of Python version 3.7, dictionaries are ordered . In Python 3.6 and earlier, dictionaries are unordered .
content.html: As of Python version 3.7, dictionaries are ordered. In Python 3.6 and earlier, dictionaries are unordered.

content.text: Dictionaries are written with curly brackets, and have keys and values:
content.html: Dictionaries are written with curly brackets, and have keys and values:

content.code_html:
thisdict = {
  "brand": "Ford",
  "model": "Mustang",
  "year": 1964
}
print(thisdict)

content.text: Dictionary Items
Dictionary items are ordered, changeable, and do not allow duplicates.
content.html: Dictionary items are ordered, changeable, and do not allow duplicates.

content.text: Dictionary items are presented in key:value pairs, and can be referred to by using the key name.
content.html: Dictionary items are presented in key:value pairs, and can be referred to by using the key name.

content.code_html:
thisdict = {
  "brand": "Ford",
  "model": "Mustang",
  "year": 1964
}
print(thisdict["brand"])

content.text: Ordered or Unordered?
As of Python version 3.7, dictionaries are ordered . In Python 3.6 and earlier, dictionaries are unordered .
content.html: As of Python version 3.7, dictionaries are ordered. In Python 3.6 and earlier, dictionaries are unordered.

content.text: When we say that dictionaries are ordered, it means that the items have a defined order, and that order will not change.
content.html: When we say that dictionaries are ordered, it means that the items have a defined order, and that order will not change.

content.text: Unordered means that the items do not have a defined order, you cannot refer to an item by using an index.
content.html: Unordered means that the items do not have a defined order, you cannot refer to an item by using an index.

content.text: Changeable
Dictionaries are changeable, meaning that we can change, add or remove items after the dictionary has been created.
content.html: Dictionaries are changeable, meaning that we can change, add or remove items after the dictionary has been created.

content.text: Duplicates Not Allowed
Dictionaries cannot have two items with the same key:
content.html: Dictionaries cannot have two items with the same key:

content.code_html:
thisdict = {
  "brand": "Ford",
  "model": "Mustang",
  "year": 1964,
  "year": 2020
}
print(thisdict)

content.text: Dictionary Length
To determine how many items a dictionary has, use the len() function:
content.html: To determine how many items a dictionary has, use the len() function:

content.code_html: print(len(thisdict))

content.text: Dictionary Items - Data Types
The values in dictionary items can be of any data type:
content.html: The values in dictionary items can be of any data type:

content.code_html:
thisdict = {
  "brand": "Ford",
  "electric": False,
  "year": 1964,
  "colors": ["red", "white", "blue"]
}

content.text: type()
From Python's perspective, dictionaries are defined as objects with the data type 'dict':
content.html: From Python's perspective, dictionaries are defined as objects with the data type 'dict':

content.code_html:
thisdict = {
  "brand": "Ford",
  "model": "Mustang",
  "year": 1964
}
print(type(thisdict))

content.text: The dict() Constructor
It is also possible to use the dict() constructor to make a dictionary.
content.html: It is also possible to use the dict() constructor to make a dictionary.

content.code_html:
thisdict = dict(name = "John", age = 36, country = "Norway")
print(thisdict)

content.text: Python Collections (Arrays)
There are four collection data types in the Python programming language:
content.html: There are four collection data types in the Python programming language:

content.text: *Set items are unchangeable, but you can remove and/or add items whenever you like.
content.html: *Set items are unchangeable, but you can remove and/or add items whenever you like.

content.text: **As of Python version 3.7, dictionaries are ordered . In Python 3.6 and earlier, dictionaries are unordered .
content.html: **As of Python version 3.7, dictionaries are ordered. In Python 3.6 and earlier, dictionaries are unordered.

content.text: When choosing a collection type, it is useful to understand the properties of that type. Choosing the right type for a particular data set could mean retention of meaning, and, it could mean an increase in efficiency or security.
content.html: When choosing a collection type, it is useful to understand the properties of that type. Choosing the right type for a particular data set could mean retention of meaning, and, it could mean an increase in efficiency or security.

Which one of these is a dictionary?
content.html: Which one of these is a dictionary?
